questions.text: Which of the following hormones regulates rum calcium levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

All three hormones are responsible for regulation of serum calcium levels.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of methotrexate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase
Methotrexate is an antimetabolite. It is a folic acid analogue that inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). Methotrexate and its polyglutamate also inhibit the enzymes involved in de novo purine and thymidylate synthesis.

questions.text: A 54-year-old chronic alcoholic patient presents with altered sensorium and confusion. He also complains of weakness in both lower limbs and occasional tingling in his legs. His staple diet includes white polished rice. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Beri beri
The given clinical scenario of a 54-year-old chronic alcoholic, who consumes polished rice as a staple diet, and presents with altered sensorium and tingling sensation (neuritis), points to the diagnosis of Beri-beri.
The vitamin deficiency associated with this condition is thiamine (vitamin B1). It is commonly seen in people who consume polished rice-based monotonous diets. Diagnosis of thiamine deficiency can be established by erythrocyte transketolase activity assessment.

choices.text: Increased NADH/NAD+ ratio leads to hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient was brought to the emergency room by his relatives in a state of agitation, impaired judgment, and combativeness. His spot blood glucose level was 45 mg/dL. Yesterday, the patient went to the gym directly after work, following which he attended a party where he only consumed alcoholic beverages and skipped his meals. Which of the following is the likely cause of hypoglycemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Alcohol inhibits gluconeogenesis

The given clinical scenario of a patient who had a history of alcohol intake presenting with hypoglycemia and a state of agitation, impaired judgment, and combativeness is suggestive of alcohol (ethanol) intoxication that inhibits the process of gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: A patient came to the clinic, and the following test was performed, as shown in the image below. Which of the following is being tested here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Abduction
The test being performed here is the Trendelenburg test, which is done to check the action of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which are powerful abductors of the hip supplied by the superior gluteal nerve.
A positive Trendelenburg test on the right side indicates a right superior gluteal nerve injury, and vice versa. When the patient stands on his left foot, there is drooping of the right, this is a positive Trendelenburg test on the left side.

questions.text: A histology slide of the adrenal gland is provided below. Which of the following hormones is secreted from the zone marked as D?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Epinephrine
In the above image, the structure marked D is the adrenal medulla.  Epinephrine is secreted from the adrenal medulla.
Adrenal Medulla secretes:
- Epinephrine .
- Norepinephrine
- Dopamine

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is due to defect in the biogenesis of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Peroxisomes
Zellweger syndrome is due to a defect in the biogenesis of peroxisomes.
Zellweger syndrome is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the PEX family of genes. This results in defective beta-oxidation of very long- chain fatty acids, defective alpha oxidation, and impaired synthesis of bile acids and plasmalogens.

questions.text: During surgery for patent ductus arteriosus, which anatomical structure is most susceptible to injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Left recurrent laryngeal nerve
The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is most susceptible to injury during surgery for patent ductus arteriosus.
The left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops under the 6th arch artery while the right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops under the 4th arch artery. This occurs because the distal portion of the 6th arch disappears on the right side along with the 5th arch artery. Thus the nerve on the right side loops under the 4th arch artery.

questions.text: A child was defecating in the open in a village when he was attacked by pack of dogs. One of the attacking dogs was found dead the next day. Considering the high risk of rabies in the child he was admitted to District hospital and was given antirabiesserum (ARS) and Rabipur vaccine. Which of the following is responsible for transport of rabies virus to brain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Rabies virus to the brain is an example of Retrograde Exoplasmic transport, with the help of protein Dynein (molecular motor) In Anterograde transport, the molecular motor used is Kinesin.

questions.text: When ORS is given to the patient, Glucose is absorbed by which of the following transport mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

It is SGLT transport i.e. secondary active co-transport

questions.text: What joint is present between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Synchondrosis

The joint present between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone is called synchondrosis.
Synchondrosis refers to the primary cartilaginous joints in which the advancing areas of ossification are separated by hyaline cartilage. They are temporary joints and are associated with growth. Hyaline cartilage has the ability to ossify with age, thus making these joints undergo synostosis (fusion) once the growth is complete. An example of this type of joint is the epiphyseal plate between the epiphysis and diaphysis of long bones

questions.text: Identify the liver segment marked in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
VIII
The highlighted liver segment is segment VIII.

A horizontal plane known as the portal plane divides the liver where the portal vein bifurcates and becomes horizontal. This divides each section of the liver into superior and inferior segments:
- Left lateral section: segment II above and segment III below the portal plane
- Left medial section: segment Iva above and segment IVb below the portal plane
- Right anterior (or medial) section: segment VIII above and segment V below the portal plane
- Right posterior (or lateral) section: segment VII above and segment VI below the portal

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with diarrhoea for a few weeks. His family members report observing abnormal behaviour that they had not noticed earlier. Recently, he has developed a rash around his neck, as shown below. This rash flares up when exposed to sunlight. Which of the following supplements is most likely to benefit the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Nicotinamide
The above clinical scenario of a patient with diarrhoea, abnormal behaviour (probably dementia) and rash around his neck (casal’s neck) points to a diagnosis of pellagra which is secondary to nicotinamide/ niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency. Hence this patient will benefit from nicotinamide supplements.
Niacin deficiency is mostly seen among people eating corn/maize-based diets, which are low in niacin and tryptophan. Excess leucine in jowar and maize disrupts the conversion of tryptophan to niacin.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of repeated pain over the medial canthus and chronic use of nasal decongestants presents to the OPD with high-grade fever, chills, headache, and bilateral proptosis. On eliciting further history, it was confirmed that proptosis began in the right eye, and a few days later, the left eye was also affected. Fundoscopy reveals papilloedema. On examination, damage to the abducens nerve was noted. Which of the following ocular movements will be impaired?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Lateral
The given clinical scenario, with recurrent episodes of headache and pain over the medial canthus and repeated use of nasal decongestants, suggests that the patient was suffering from sinusitis, which has most likely resulted in cavernous sinus thrombosis, and the injury of the abducens nerve will affect the lateral ocular movement as it supplies the lateral rectus muscle of the eye.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries is being palpated in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Posterior tibial artery
The given image shows the physician’s fingertips between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon, and the artery being palpated here is the posterior tibial artery.
The posterior tibial artery can be felt by keeping the foot relaxed between plantar and dorsiflexion and palpating against the distal tibia behind and below the medial malleolus.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders has an impaired thermoregulatory mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Heat stroked
Heat stroke is a severe heat disorder that occurs when the body’s thermoregulatory mechanism fails. Sweating is absent in this condition.
Heat stroke is likely to occur when the body temperature rises to 106-108 °F (normal 98.6 °F).
Heatstroke symptoms indicate a complete loss of thermoregulatory function. Common vital sign abnormalities include tachypnea, various tachycardias, hypotension, and a widened pulse pressure.

questions.text: Ingestation all if surfactant are produced by which cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Type 2 pneumocytes produce the surfactant in gestational life.

questions.text: Identify the labelled structure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Internal capsule
The labelled structure is the Internal capsule.
The internal capsule is a component of the white matter of the brain. They contain projection fibers. It can be divided into the following parts:
- anterior limb
- genu
- posterior limb
- retrolenticular/retrolentiform portion
- sublenticular/sublentiform portion
The anterior limb of the internal capsule carries the fronto- pontine fibers, while the genu carries the corticonuclear tract

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of inhibin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Inhibits FSH

Inhibin acts by inhibiting the production of FSH.
The inhibins are produced by the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle, as well as other tissues, including the pituitary, the brain, the adrenal gland, the kidney, the bone marrow, the corpus luteum, and the placenta. Inhibin A is produced by the corpus luteum whereas inhibin B is mainly produced by granulosa cells of the follicle.

questions.text: Maximum water absorption occurs from which part of nephron?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 
2/3 of the water in tubular fluid is absorbed in PCT (maximum) with the help of Aquaporin – 1 13-15% water is absorbed in CD under the control of ADH

questions.text: Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Gower’s signis demonstrated in a child in your OPD.Work-up shows decreased/altered dystroph in protein. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

In Duchenne muscular dystrophy – Dystrophin is absent Becker’s 2muscular dystrophy – dystrophin is present but reduced The gower’s sign is typically seen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

questions.text: An infant demonstrates lethargy, vomiting, and convulsions after a few sessions of breastfeeding. The patient was diagnosed with hyperammonemia type-1. Which of the following statement is the enzyme deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I
The enzyme defective in hyperammonemia type-1 is carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I).
CPS I catalyzes the rate-limiting step in the urea cycle and is present in the mitochondria. This reaction uses NH, and CO2 as substrates to generate one molecule of carbamoyl phosphate. It is a mitochondrial enzyme. Its defect leads to hyperammonemia type 1.

questions.text: An infant is brought by his parents with complaints that his urine turns black on standing. Which of the following metabolic disorders is likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Alkaptonuria
Blackening of urine on standing is characteristic of alkaptonuria.
Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase/homogentisic acid 1, 2- dioxygenase, which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate. The defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of homogentisate, which is then excreted in the urine.

questions.text: Which of the following processes is mediated by CRISPR CAS-9 technology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Gene editing
CRISPR CAS-9 technology mediates the process of gene editing.
CRISPR is Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats
- CRISPR-Cas9 is a genome editing tool and this system enables select bacteria to respond to and eliminate invading genetic material. 
- CRISPRS are transcribed into an RNA sequence that directs the Cas9 to a sequence, leading to its cleavage. 
- Gene editing uses an artificial guide RNA that binds Cas9 and is complementary to a DNA sequence of interest and Cas9 induces the break of double-stranded DNA.

questions.text: Which of the following structures will be present in the area marked below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pterygopalatine ganglion

The pterygopalatine ganglion will be present in the area marked in the image above which is the pterygopalatine fossa.
The pterygopalatine ganglion is a parasympathetic ganglion located in the pterygopalatine fossa, a small, cone-shaped depression situated deep in the skull. This fossa is located posterior to the maxilla (upper jaw) and adjacent to the nasal cavity.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child has a history of biting his lips and fingers. On evaluation, you notice lip lacerations, missing sections of his fingers, and developmental delay. Lab reports reveal hyperuricemia. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase
The given clinical scenario of self-mutilating behavior, delayed developmental milestones and hyperuricemia is highly suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. It occurs due to the complete deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine- guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) involved in the salvage pathway.

questions.text: Which of the following ion channels in peripheral chemoreceptors is oxygen-sensitive?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 K+
Potassium channels in the peripheral chemoreceptors are oxygen-sensitive.
Type I glomus cells (carotid and aortic body) have 02- sensitive K+ channels, whose conductance is reduced in proportion to the degree of hypoxia.
This reduces the K+ efflux, depolarizing the cell and causing Ca2+ influx.

questions.text: Calcium binds to which of the following proteins during smooth muscle contraction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Calmodulin

Calcium binds to calmodulin during smooth muscle contraction.
Increased cytoplasmic Ca2+ binds to and activates calcium- binding proteins (calmodulin, troponin) or activates protein kinases (or phospholipase C) to bring about physiological effects.

questions.text: A 23-year-old chronic alcoholic male presents to the hospital with a history of abdominal pain, dehydration, weakness, and lethargy. Which of the following kidney segments is associated with maximum water reabsorption?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Proximal convoluted tubule
The proximal convoluted tubule is the site of maximum water reabsorption about 67% of the filtered water.
The driving force for water reabsorption is a trans tubular osmotic gradient established by the reabsorption of solutes.

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte imbalances results in increased nerve excitability?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Hypocalcemia causes loss of membrane stabalising action of calcium and that increases the neuronal and muscle excitability which is called Tetany.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme deficiency is likely to cause Von Gierke's disease
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Glucose 6 phosphatase Glucose 6 phosphatase is likely enzyme deficiency to cause Von gierke’s Diseas.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby presented with failure to thrive and delayed milestones. On examination, he had elevated transaminases and mild hypotonia without any organomegaly. Ophthalmological examination showed a cherry red spot in the macula. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tay-Sachs disease

The above clinical scenario of an infant with failure to thrive & delayed milestones, elevated transaminases, and cherry red spot on the macula without organomegaly points to a diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease.
Tay Sach disease is an autosomal recessive disease. It occurs due to a deficiency of hexosaminidase A leading to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside. It presents with progressive neurodegeneration, foam cells (lipid-laden macrophages), a “cherry-red” spot on the macula, and developmental delay but does not have hepatosplenomegaly.

questions.text: In the given left ventricular pressure-volume loop, which of the following corresponds to the ‘c’ wave of JVP?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Point B to Point C
In the given left ventricular pressure-volume loop, the event that occurs between Points B and C is iso-volumetric contraction, which corresponds to the ‘c’ wave of JVP.
In iso-volumetric contraction, the ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.

questions.text: Which of the following two monosaccharides are constituents of lactulose?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Galactose and Fructose
Lactulose is a disaccharide composed of two simple sugars, galactose and fructose linked by a ẞ-1,4-glycosidic linkage

questions.text: A patient presented with a fracture of the structure marked below following a road traffic accident. Which of the following symptoms will be seen in this is patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Anosmia
The structure marked in the given image is the cribriform plate of the ethmoid and fracture to the cribriform plate will lead to anosmia as the olfactory nerve fibres pierce through it.
Olfactory nerves transmit olfactory information from the sensory receptors in the nasal mucosa to the brain. Damage to these fibres can disrupt this pathway, resulting in a loss of smell. A cribriform plate fracture may also lead to a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak, manifesting as clear, watery nasal discharge.

questions.text: Which of the following post-translational modifications (PTM) is associated with the synthesis of haemoglobin, collagen and immunoglobulin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Subunit aggregation
Haemoglobin, collagen, and immunoglobin are proteins that are synthesized as subunits and undergo subunit aggregation during post-translational modifications (PTM).
Adult haemoglobin is synthesized separately as 2 alpha chains and 2 beta chains and then aggregated together to form (a232) chains.
Collagen is synthesized as pre-procollagen inside cells and released as tropocollagen which aggregates into collagen fibrils through covalent bonds.
Immunoglobulins are components of the immune system and are divided into 5 classes. However, each Immunoglobulin has two heavy chains and two light chains synthesized separately and then aggregated.

questions.text: During surgical intervention on the great saphenous vein situated 2.5 cm anterior to the medial malleolus, which structure should be protected from damage during the application of ligatures around the vein?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Saphenous nerve

During surgery on the great saphenous vein located 2.5 cm anterior to the medial malleolus, care must be taken to protect the nearby saphenous nerve from damage during ligature placement around the vein.
The Saphenous nerve accompanies the Great Saphenous Vein medially from the ankle to the level of the knee and supplies cutaneous sensation to the medial leg and ankle. Thus it is more prone to injury during stripping of GSV.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with swelling at the base of the thumb after falling on an outstretched hand while playing football. Which of the following is most likely to be to be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Scaphoid

The history of falls on the outstretched hand and swelling at the base of the thumb suggests the diagnosis of a scaphoid fracture.
A scaphoid fracture is the most common carpal fracture. Direct axial compression or hyperextension of the wrist, such as with a fall onto an outstretched hand, results in a scaphoid fracture.

choices.text: Decrease in bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: Which of the following will increase the GFR?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Decrease in bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure

A decrease in Bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure causes an increase in glomerular filtration rate (GFR).
A decrease in Bowman’s Capsule Hydrostatic Pressure increases GFR because it reduces the opposing force to filtration, thus enhancing the net filtration pressure and increasing the amount of filtrate formed.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient presents with diarrhoea and pellagra-like photosensitive skin eruptions for the last 5 years. Her vital examinations are normal. Urine analysis reveals an increase in the amino acid levels but normal levels of 5-hydroxyindole acetic acid (5-HIAA). What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hartnup disease
The above clinical history of a 16-year-old child presenting with diarrhoea and pellagra-like photosensitive skin eruptions with urine analysis showing an increase in the amino acid levels and normal 5-HIAA levels is suggestive of Hartnup disease.
Amino acids are reabsorbed in the kidneys in the proximal convoluted tubule. Aminoaciduria points towards a pathology.

questions.text: A patient presents with an inability to shrug his shoulders after a fall from the stairs. On examination, an injury to the posterior triangle of his neck is noted. Which of the following structures is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Spinal accessory nerve

In the given scenario, the patient is unable to shrug his shoulders due to an injury to the spinal accessory nerve, which is present in the posterior triangle of the neck and supplies the trapezius muscle.
The spinal accessory nerve innervates the sternocleidomastoid just before entering the posterior triangle.

questions.text: What is the epithelial lining of the trachea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium
The trachea is lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium.
The trachea is a tube-like structure that allows air to pass between the larynx and the bronchi.
The trachealis muscle is a smooth muscle located at the posterior wall of the trachea. It connects the ends of the C- shaped tracheal cartilage rings and completes the posterior part of the tracheal wall.

questions.text: Mode of action of Dicumarol?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Vitamin K inhibition It inhibit the enzyme Epoxide Reductase. This enzyme converts Hyproxyqunone ( Active form ) from it epoxide state ( Inactive Form ) of vit .K These both are forms of Vit .k

questions.text: While performing an endoscopy, a constriction is felt at the oesophageal junction, 25 cm from the upper incisors. Which of the following structures is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Arch of aorta
The constriction is felt due to the arch of aorta and left bronchus crossing the esophagus at 25 cm from the upper incisor teeth.
Normally, the esophagus shows 3 constrictions at the following levels measured from upper incisors:
- Junction of the esophagus with cricopharynx (15 cm from the incisor teeth)
- Crossed by arch of aorta and left bronchus (25 cm from the incisor teeth)
- It pierces the diaphragm (40 cm from the incisor teeth)

questions.text: Which is of the following enzymes is responsible for the respiratory burst in neutrophils?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

NADPH oxidase

The deficiency of NADPH oxidase is responsible for the respiratory burst in neutrophils.

NADPH +202 --- > NADP+ +202- + 2H+

NADPH oxidase in the inflammatory cells (neutrophils, eosinophils, monocytes, and macrophages) produces superoxide anion by reducing oxygen by a process of respiratory burst during phagocytosis.

questions.text: Which of the following molecular analysis methods is used to detect monkeypox virus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Real time PCR

Real-time PCR is used to detect monkeypox virus which contains enveloped double-stranded DNA.
Real-time PCR helps quantify the PCR and gives an estimate of the pathogen DNA load in the specimen. It uses fluorescent dyes or specific DNA probes. It is also known as qPCR (Quantitative PCR)

questions.text: Match the following genetic diseases with their respective trinucleotide repeat sequences.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A.

questions.text: On uterine contraction, there is cervical dilation and Delivery. Which of the following shows similar mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Distichiasis: A condition where an extra row of eyelashes arises from the meibomian gland openings on the posterior aspect of the eyelid margin. These abnormal lashes can cause irritation and corneal damage Other options: B) Trichiasis: Misdirected eyelashes that grow inward toward the cornea, often secondary to chronic inflammation or trauma C) Tylosis: Thickening of the eyelid margin due to chronic inflammation or irritation D) Madarosis: Loss of eyelashes or eyebrows, commonly seen in leprosy, alopecia, or chronic blepharitis

questions.text: When does the anterior fontanelle close?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

12-24 months
The anterior fontanelle ideally closes between 18-24 months. However, the closest answer in the given options is 12-24 months of age.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of splenectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Bone marrow failure

Among the given options, bone marrow failure is not an indication of splenectomy.
Overall, the most common indication for splenectomy is trauma to the spleen, whether external (blunt or penetrating) or iatrogenic (e.g., during operative procedures for other reasons).

questions.text: A patient with chronic stable angina presents with pedal edema, breathlessness and other symptoms of heart failure. Which of the following drug can increase longevity in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Lisinopril Drugs increasing survival or inhibits mortality via inhibiting remodelling risk in CHF patients are: • RAAS inhibitors- ACE inhibitors (pril), ARBs (sartans) & Spironolactone • Sympatholytics- Beta blockers • Vasadilators- Hydralazine Other drugs used in CHF are providing symptomatic relief only.

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary lymphoid organ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Thymus
Thymus and bone marrow are the primary lymphoid organs (also known as central lymphoid organs). It is the place where immature lymphocytes develop, differentiate, proliferate, and mature into immune competent cells.
A secondary lymphoid organ (also known as a peripheral lymphoid organ) is where the antigen is localized so that it can be effectively exposed to mature lymphocytes. These include the spleen, lymph nodes, tonsils, sppendix, and Peyer’s patches.

questions.text: Which of the following blood groups can be given to a patient having Bombay blood group?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

OH

Among the given options, OH blood group blood can be transfused to Bombay blood group patients.
The H antigen is present in all four blood groups (A, B, AB, and O). A rare blood group where there is an absence of the H antigen is known as the Bombay blood group. The absence of this H antigen results in the absence of A and B antigens. Their plasma contains anti-A, anti-B, and strong anti-H antibodies. Therefore, they do not react with anti-A, anti-B, and anti-AB antiserums, and get recognized as O blood group on cell typing.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain abdomen, diarrhea, and a stepladder pattern of fever for the past five days. He also complains of a headache and malaise. Which of the following is the best screening test to perform now if typhoid is suspected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Blood culture

The best test to screen a symptomatic patient for typhoid in the first week is blood culture.
Enteric fever (typhoid fever) is caused by Salmonella species. The patient presents with stepladder pyrexia (fever), abdominal pain, diarrhoea, headache, and malaise.

questions.text: Which of the following is used in Blood spillage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Sodium Hypochlorite For Blood spills we use hypochlorite (sodium/calcium)

questions.text: Which of the following tests can be done for measuring long-term glucose control in patients with diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

HbA1c

In patients with diabetes mellitus, HbA1c is the best method to measure long-term glucose control.
Glycated hemoglobin, reported as HbA1c, has been used to monitor glycemic control in patients with diabetes for many years. HbA1c results from the attachment of glucose to the N-terminal valine of the hemoglobin ẞ-chain.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with cough for 15 days. On examination, cervical lymphadenopathy was noted and the lymph node biopsy showed the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tuberculosis
The histopathological findings and clinical history are suggestive of tuberculosis.
Once Mycobacterium tuberculosis enters the macrophage, it inhibits the formation of the phagolysosome. This allows it to replicate unchecked. M. tuberculosis recruits a host protein coronin to block the fusion of phagosome and lysosome. Th1 response to M. tuberculosis is mounted about three weeks following the infection. The antigen-presenting cells (APCs) present mycobacterial antigens to the T-cells in the lymph nodes and release IL-12 and IL-18 to cause the differentiation of T-cells into Th1 cells. Th1 cells produce IFN-Y. IFN-y is the critical step in the body’s defense against M. tuberculosis. It acts by activating macrophages, causing phagolysosome maturation, and inducing nitric oxide synthase enzyme to form more reactive nitrogen species. It also mobilizes anti- bacterial compounds like defensins and stimulates autophagy.

questions.text: Which of the following is decreased in acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Albumin

Albumin, an acute phase reactant, is decreased in acute inflammation.
Inflammation results in changes in the levels of certain proteins called acute phase reactants (APR). These changes contribute to the body’s defense mechanisms and adaptive capabilities. The levels of APR are primarily regulated by cytokines produced during the inflammatory process, such as interleukin-6 (IL-6).

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Rivaroxaban?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Factor Xa inhibition

Rivaroxaban is an oral direct factor Xa inhibitor. They represent a new class of oral anticoagulant drugs that do not require monitoring.
This group of drugs inhibit factor Xa in the final common pathway of clotting [conversion of Prothrombin (Factor II) to thrombin (Factor lla)]. They are given as fixed doses and have a rapid onset of action.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Apixaban?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Factor Xa inhibitor

Apixaban, a novel oral anticoagulant (NOAC) is a factor Xa inhibitor that is used in the treatment of VTE (Venous Thrombo Embolism)/DVT and in its prophylaxis after major orthopedic surgery.
Direct factor Xa inhibitors:
- Rivaroxaban
- Apixaban
- Edoxaban
- Betrixaban

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman on antidiabetic therapy for the last 10 years has experienced three episodes of vaginal candida infection in the past 2 years. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Canagliflozin

In this case of a 50-year-old diabetic patient with recurrent episodes of candidiasis, Canagliflozin must be avoided as it is a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor, can increase the risk of genital fungal infections, including vaginal candida infections, as it promotes glycosuria (increased glucose in the urine), which can create a favourable environment for yeast growth.

questions.text: A patient comes to the emergency with history of IV drug abuse and developed infection. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Sodium Hypochlorite For Blood spills we use hypochlorite (sodium/calcium)

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient on immunosuppressive therapy presents with a cough, fever and pneumonitis. Urine examination shows the following basophilic inclusion bodies. Which of the following organisms is responsible for the infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cytomegalovirus
The most likely causative agent is cytomegalovirus (CMV) based on the clinical symptoms of immunosuppression and the presence of the owl’s eye appearance on urinary examination.
A cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion surrounded by a clear halo known as an owl’s eye appearance.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl presents with café-au-lait macules and lisch nodules. What is the most likely diagnosis?
NF-Neurofibromatosis
TSC- Tuberous sclerosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

NF-1

The diagnosis of the patient with café-au-lait macules and lisch nodules is Neurofibromatosis- 1.
Neurofibromatosis (NF) is an autosomal dominant disorder. NF type 1 (NF-1) is the most prevalent type and is caused by loss of function mutation of the NF-1 gene. The protein affected is neurofibromin. NF-I is also known as von Recklinghausen’s disease.

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of high fever for 5 days and altered sensorium. He also gave a history of two seizure episodes one day ago. Peripheral smear shows the following findings. What is the drug of choice in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Artesunate

The given scenario of high fever. Altered sensorium and seizures and peripheral smear showing rings (headphones appearance) points towards the diagnosis of severe Plasmodium falciparum malaria, and the drug of choice for this condition is artesunate.
Artesunate-based combination therapy is given at a dose of 2.4 mg/kg stat IV, followed by 2.4 mg/kg at 12 and 24 hours, and then daily if necessary.

questions.text: A young man presents to the ER with complaints of sudden onset nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of rice watery diarrhea. He gives a history of having food from a nearby bakery 2 days ago. Selective culture media is shown below. Identify the likely organism.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vibrio cholerae

The given clinical scenario of food poisoning with rice watery diarrhea and yellow-coloured colonies on thiosulfate citrate bile salts sucrose agar (TCBS) is suggestive of vibrio cholera.
Vibrio cholerae is a comma-shaped, gram-negative bacillus with darting motility. It has a single polar flagellum. It causes cholera, an acute diarrheal disease. It is marked by painless, profuse, watery diarrhea with flecks of mucus (rice-water stools) associated with effortless vomiting.

questions.text: A patient presents to the ER with complaints of headache, seizures and blurred vision. His BP was recorded as 220/120 mmHg. Which of the following will be the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

IV labetalol
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a hypertensive crisis (BP > 160/110 mmHg). The preferred drug to manage a hypertensive patient in an emergency is IV labetalol.
Intravenous labetalol is the drug of choice for controlling BP in a hypertensive crisis. It is effective, has a rapid onset of action, and has a good safety profile.
Labetalol is a nonselective ẞ blocker and vascular a blocker. It should be avoided in patients with asthma and congestive heart failure due to bronchoconstriction.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a unilateral throbbing headache associated with nausea and vomiting. She has had similar episodes in the past where the headache usually lasts for 1-2 days, and she prefers sitting in a dark room during the attacks. She also gives a history of a myocardial infarction 2 years ago. Which of the following drugs cannot be prescribed to this patient to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sumatriptan

The clinical vignette is suggestive of an acute attack of migraine. Sumatriptan is contraindicated in a patient with a history of myocardial infarction.
Triptans are selective 5HT 1B/1D agonists. They are indicated in the management of acute attacks of migraine. They act by arresting the nociceptive nerve signalling in the trigeminovascular system. They also act by vasoconstricting, not only the intracranial vessels but other vessels too. Hence it is contraindicated in patients with a history of ischemic or vasospastic coronary artery disease (history of stroke or transient ischemic attacks), cerebrovascular or peripheral vascular disease, hemiplegic or basilar migraines, or ischemic bowel diseases. Triptans are also contraindicated in patients with uncontrolled hypertension.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with abdominal pain and vomiting. He had similar episodes in the past along with steatorrhea, weight loss, and fatigue. Which of the following types of necrosis is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Fat necrosis

The given clinical history of a chronic alcoholic patient presenting with abdominal pain and vomiting and similar complaints in the past with steatorrhea, weight loss, and fatigue is suggestive of chronic pancreatitis. Fat necrosis is
Seen in such patients. Fat necrosis refers to the destruction of fat tissue due to various reasons like injury, surgery, etc. Examples of fat necrosis include pancreatitis, breast trauma, and panniculitis.

questions.text: Which organism cannot be grown on an Artificial culture media?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

The organism which do not grow on artificial culture media are: 1. Chlamydia 2. Rickettsia 3. Ehrilichia 4. Anaplasma 5. M. leprae 6. Pathogenic Treponema

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with colicky abdominal pain, joint pain and palpable purpura. Urine analysis shows only red blood cells with no other significant findings. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 IgA vasculitis

The given clinical presentation of palpable purpura, colicky abdominal pain and hematuria point towards a diagnosis of IgA vasculitis also known as Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP).

questions.text: A patient admitted with the complaints of severe headache, fever, nuchal rigidity. A lumbar puncture was performed that showed Protein 1.0 g/L, glucose 2.2 mmol/L, white cell count 150/mm3, 90% polymorphs. On microscopy the organism was noted to have differential motility i.e tumbling motility at 25° and non-motile at 37°. Identify the organism
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Listeria Painful salivary glands (parotitis) and testicular swelling = mumps virus. Bacteria has tumbling motility at 250C and is non motile at 37?C = listeria

questions.text: Which of the following is a tumor marker for carcinoid tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

5-hydroxy indole acetic acid

The tumor marker for carcinoid tumors is 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid.
The carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors arising from enterochromaffin cells that can occur anywhere in the GIT. The most common site is the appendix followed by the ileum and rectum. A tumor with liver metastasis is likely to produce carcinoid syndrome. The image below shows the histopathologic appearance of carcinoid tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common bacteria found as part of the normal flora of the conjunctiva?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Staphylococcus epidermidis

Staphylococcus epidermidis is present as a normal flora of conjunctiva.
The normal flora of the conjunctiva consists of a variety of microorganisms that exist harmlessly and help maintain ocular health by preventing the colonization of pathogenic organisms. The most commonly found bacteria in the conjunctiva include:
Staphylococcus epidermidis (most common), staphylococcus aureus, corynebacterium species, streptococcus viridans, propionibacterium acnes, etc.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the haematologist with complaints of weakness and fatigue. Lab investigations reveal a decrease in the haemoglobin and reticulocyte count while WBC and platelet counts are normal. Bone marrow shows a selective decrease in the erythroid precursors. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pure red cell aplasia

The given scenario along with lab investigations showing a decrease in haemoglobin and reticulocyte count, normal WBC, and platelet count with a selective decrease in the erythroid precursors are suggestive of pure red cell aplasia.
Pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) is a primary marrow disorder that causes the suppression of erythroid progenitors only. One cause is acute parvovirus B19 infection which may lead to an aplastic crisis in patients who already had underlying hemolytic anemia. The hallmark of PRCA, in an otherwise normal marrow, is the absence of erythroblasts.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in GERD?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Metoclopramide

Metoclopramide has both antiemetic and prokinetic action and is used in the treatment of GERD.
In GERD, the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) weakens or relaxes, allowing stomach acid to flow back into the esophagus, causing irritation and symptoms like heartburn and regurgitation. Metoclopramide is useful in this condition because it increases LES tone, preventing acid reflux, and enhances gastric emptying by promoting gastrointestinal motility. Additionally, it reduces nausea and vomiting by blocking dopamine D2 receptors in the central nervous system. These combined effects help alleviate the symptoms and discomfort associated with GERD.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs is associated with visual adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ethambutol

Ethambutol is associated with ophthalmic toxicity.
Ethambutol inhibits arabinose transferase III, thereby decreasing arabinogalactan biosynthesis. This results in, disruption in mycobacterial cell wall synthesis. It is primarily excreted unchanged by kidneys and accumulation occurs in renal failure. Ethambutol does not undergo hepatic metabolism and can be safely prescribed for the treatment of TB in patients with hepatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is given to prevent neural tube defects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Vitamin B9

Folic acid (Vitamin B9) is given to prevent the incidence of neural tube defects.
Folic acid deficiency is implicated in neural tube defects like spina bifida, encephalocele, and anencephaly.
Supplementation of folic acid, in doses of 400 µg/day, prior to conception has been shown to cause a significant reduction in the incidence of spina bifida and other neural tube defects.

choices.text: Metastatic calcification with normal serum calcium level
Metastatic calcification with increased serum calcium level
Dystrophic calcification with normal serum calcium level
Dystrophic calcification with increased serum calcium level

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a history of fever and weight loss presented with cervical lymphadenopathy. Biopsy revealed revealed granulomatous necrotizing inflammation. Which of the following statements is true with respect to the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Dystrophic calcification with normal serum calcium level
The given clinical history of fever, weight loss, and cervical lymphadenopathy showing granulomatous necrotizing inflammation suggests the diagnosis of tuberculosis.
Dystrophic calcification with normal serum calcium level is seen in tuberculosis.

questions.text: A child with a history of sore-throat was later found to have cola- colored urine. What is the most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Streptococcus pyogenes Sore throat +Puffed face +Cola coloured Urine = strep pyogens.

questions.text: A 28-year-old truck driver presents with painful multiple ulcers on his penis 3 days after unprotected sexual intercourse. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Chancroid

Multiple painful genital ulcers 3 days after unprotected Intercourse is indicative of Chancroid or Soft Chancre.
Chancroid is a type of sexually transmitted infection (STI) that is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi, a gram-negative coccobacillus. It presents with painful genital ulceration along with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy that may develop into buboes. Auto-inoculation by the organism can result in new ulcers merging with the older ones. Hence, they are called “kissing ulcers.”

questions.text: What is the Drug of choice for Hyperthyroidism in first trimester of Pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Propylthiouracil Carbimazole & Methimazole are thioamides group drug and these drugs have risk of teratogenicity (Aplasia cutis) so not safe in first trimester of pregnancy. In second and third trimester they can be used as PTU is not a safe drug overall because of risk of agranulocytosis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with fever, sore throat, and dyspnea. On oral examination, a pseudomembrane is seen over the tonsils. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin produced by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Inhibition of elongation factor-2 (EF-2)

This child with pseudomembrane over tonsil has diphtheria, in which the toxin inactivates the elongation factor EF-2.
Diphtheria toxin is an exotoxin that consists of two fragments – A and B. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Fragment B helps in binding the toxin to the cells while fragment A inactivates the elongation factor (EF-2) responsible for protein synthesis. Pseudomonas aeruginosa also produces toxins with a similar mechanism of action.

questions.text: A patient presented to hospital with chest pain. ECG of the patient confirms it to be non ST elevation myocardial infarction. Which of the following drug useful in this patient acts by inhibiting platelet aggregation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Clopidogrel Treatment of NON-STEMI: MONA • Morphine • Oxygen • NTG • Anti-platelets Clopidogrel is irreversible P2Y12 inhibitor, used as antiplatelet drug. Most commonly used antiplatelet is Aspirin, which is irreversible COX inhibitor. Streptokinase is fibrinolytic agent, used in STEMI patients. Heparin & warfarin are anticoagulants.

questions.text: A female washing clothes in cold water exhibited color change of her hands from pallor to red. Which of the following drug is best suited for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Calcium channel blockers It’s a case of peripheral vascular disease (PVD). Drugs used in PVD are vasodilators. CCBs (dipines) are best arterial dilators for treating these patients and avoid risk.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has dual activity against hepatitis B and HIV both?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tenofovir

Tenofovir is an acyclic nucleotide analog used in the treatment of hepatitis B and HIV.
The preferred first-line regimen for managing HIV-1 and hepatitis B co-infection is tenofovir + lamivudine + dolutegravir.
Tenofovir is an acyclic nucleotide analog that is used as first- line therapy for the treatment of chronic hepatitis B and lamivudine-resistant chronic hepatitis B. It is also a potent antiretroviral agent used in the treatment of HIV infection.

questions.text: Echocardiography of a patient showed mitral stenosis with vegetation present on the mitral valve. The image of the histopathological study of the vegetation is given below. Identify the finding.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aschoff bodies
The image of the histopathological study depicts Aschoff bodies. This feature is suggestive of rheumatic valvular disease.
Aschoff’s bodies are the lesions found in the heart during acute rheumatic fever. They are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells, and occasional plasma cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence, they are also called caterpillar cells.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was brought to the emergency room with complaints of continuous diarrhea with rice water stools. A microscopic examination of a stool sample is shown in the image below. All the following can be used as a transport medium for this causative organism except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Stuart Media
The clinical vignette consisting of rice water stools and the image showing the characteristic fish in stream appearance is suggestive of Vibrio cholerae for which Stuart media cannot be used as a transport medium. Stuart media is used as a transport medium for the Neisseria group of organisms.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man came with complaints of fever and chills since the last one week. On examination, tachycardia and low BP are present. Peripheral smear findings are given below. What is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Plasmodium falciparum
The given clinical history of fever with chills and the peripheral smear showing multiple ring forms in RBCs are suggestive of Plasmodium falciparum.

questions.text: Relative bradycardia is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Brucellosis

Among the given options, relative bradycardia is seen in brucellosis.
Brucellosis is a zoonotic infection caused by the Brucella species, typically contracted through direct contact with infected animals or consumption of unpasteurized dairy products. The clinical presentation includes undulating fever, relative bradycardia, musculoskeletal symptoms like arthritis and myalgia, general malaise, hepatosplenomegaly, neurological symptoms in neuro brucellosis, presenting as meningitis or encephalitis. In men, epididymal-orchitis can occur, presenting as testicular pain and swelling.

questions.text: The dose-response curve (DRC) is plotted for drug A both in the presence and absence of drug B. What type of effect does drug B have on drug A?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Competitive antagonism

Drug B has a competitive antagonistic effect on drug A.
In competitive antagonism, DRC shows a parallel rightward shift. Competitive antagonism occurs when the agonist and antagonist compete for the same binding site on the receptor. The response curve for the agonist shifts to the right in a concentration-related manner by the antagonist.

questions.text: Paris green dust is used to eliminate the larval form of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Anopheles

Paris green is a commonly used larvicide agent against surface feeders like Anopheles larvae.
Paris green (Copper acetoarsenite) is an insecticide, which is a green powder that has 50% arsenious oxide. It is a stomach poison and to be effective, it must be ingested by the larvae.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical condition is a hexanucleotide repeat disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Frontotemporal dementia

Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is a hexanucleotide repeat disorder.
The C9ORF72 gene is associated with a hexanucleotide repeat expansion mutation. It is a common cause of both FTD and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The mutation leads to the production of abnormal RNA and proteins, causing cellular toxicity.

questions.text: A child presents with cleft lip, cleft palate and mental retardation. Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Patau syndrome

The given findings of cleft lip, cleft palate with mental retardation in a child are consistent with trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome).
Trisomy 13, or Patau syndrome, is characterized by forebrain and midline facial abnormalities. Patients can develop holoprosencephaly, which is characterized by fused frontal lobes and a single ventricle. Olfactory bulbs are also absent. The midline facial abnormalities seen with trisomy 13 include cleft lip, cleft palate, mental retardation, nasal defects, and a single central eye (“cyclops”). Other defects Include polydactyly, rocker-bottom feet, renal defects, and congenital heart diseases.

questions.text: A patient with HIV has a CD4 count of 170/μL. The patient’s chest radiograph shows symmetric interstitial infiltrates in the perihilar region. Histopathological findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pneumocystis pneumonia
In the given clinical scenario of an HIV patient with a CD4 count of 170/ µL and Gomori’s methenamine silver staining showing crescent-shaped cysts with X-ray findings of symmetric interstitial infiltrates mainly in the perihilar region are suggestive of pneumocystis pneumonia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of hypertriglyceridemia was prescribed statins to help stabilize his levels. Despite taking statins, the levels remained elevated at around 600 mg/dL. Which of the following drugs can be added to help lower his triglyceride levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Gemfibrozil
In this case of a 50-year-old patient with a history of hypertriglyceridemia who was prescribed statins for his elevated triglyceride levels and still had elevated triglyceride levels, gemfibrozil can be given to help lower his triglyceride levels.
Gemfibrozil belongs to the fibrate group of drugs that bind to peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARa), which stimulate fatty acid oxidation, reduce the expression of apo C-III (inhibitor of lipolysis), and thereby reduce triglyceride levels.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a history of diarrhea and flask-shaped ulcers in the intestine. Microscopic findings reveal quadrinucleated cysts. Which of the following can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Metronidazole + Paromomycin
This patient’s clinical features of diarrhea and flask-shaped ulcers with quadrinucleate cysts are suggestive of amoebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. The most appropriate treatment for this patient is metronidazole (or tinidazole) + a luminal amoebicide like paromomycin, diloxanide furoate, or iodoquinone.

questions.text: Dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Celiac disease

Dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with celiac disease.
Dermatitis herpetiformis, also known as Duhring’s disease is an auto-immune disease associated with HLA DQ-2 and HLA DQ-8. The antibodies target epidermal transglutaminase-3, resulting in the collection of neutrophils at the dermal papilla. This condition is closely associated with celiac disease (gluten-sensitive enteropathy).

questions.text: Which of the following vectors is associated with Orientia Tsutsugamushi?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Trombiculid mite

Trombiculid mite is the vector responsible for the transmission of scrub typhus caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi.
Scrub typhus, also known as chigger-borne typhus, is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi. The vector is trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. The incubation period is 1-3 weeks. Patients develop a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, along with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. It can be associated with fever, headache, and conjunctival injection. Meningoencephalitis, myocarditis, and pneumonia can be seen in severe cases.

questions.text: In a normal curve, what is the percentage of the distribution that falls within one standard deviation of the mean?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

68

questions.text: A vegetable vendor was found dead in his apartment, and his body had undergone advanced stages of decomposition. Which of the following methods can be used to identify him a week later?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

DNA profiling

DNA profiling is the most reliable method for identifying a deceased person whose body has undergone advanced decomposition.
DNA profiling can also aid in identifying skeletonized or severely decomposed human remains. This process typically involves comparing the genetic profile from the remains with reference samples from relatives, often the victim’s parents.

questions.text: An urban primary health centre is functional for a population of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1 per 50,000

An urban primary health centre is functional for a population of 1 per 50,000.
- HWC-PHCs (HWC- Health and Wellness Center-Primary Health Centre): Population of 30000 in plains, 20000 in hilly/tribal areas
- Urban HWC-PHCs: Population of 50000
- Specialist UPHC/Polyclinic (urban): Population of 2.5-3 lakh

choices.text: Plan surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery
Bed rest and avoiding strenuous activity

questions.text: A 33-year-old male met with a road traffic accident. There is persistent watery discharge mixed with blood from his nose for 3 days which cannot be sniffed back. Which of the following should not be done in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Plan surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery
In the given scenario of a male presenting with watery nasal discharge mixed with blood that cannot be sniffed back following a road traffic accident is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea. Surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery should not be done in this patient.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient presented with. Sudden painless loss of vision. She has been a known diabetic for 12 years. Ophthalmoscopy shows evidence of loss of fundal features, floating debris and a dark red glow. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Vitreous haemorrhage
This patient with long-standing diabetes with sudden, painless vision loss, floating debris and a dark red glow on fundoscopic examination is most likely suffering from vitreous haemorrhage.

questions.text: Which of the following is caused by exposure to cotton dust?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bysssinosis

Byssinosis is caused by exposure to cotton dust.
Byssinosis is an occupational disease due to chronic exposure to cotton dust as in textile and rope-making industries. Chest X-ray shows hyperlucency, diaphragmatic flattening, and emphysema. A chest CT demonstrates ground glass opacities largely distributed in the basal regions with centrilobular nodules.

questions.text: The following image depicts a particular type of cataract. What history should be elicited from the patient to come to a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Blunt trauma
The above image characteristically depicts a rosette cataract. It typically follows closed globe injuries (blunt trauma), and hence is also known as the concussion cataract.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. During an autopsy, apparent bleeding was seen on the surface of his brain. Which type of hemorrhage would not be washed away under direct running water?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Subarachnoid hemorrhage
Subarachnoid haemorrhage will persist when washed under running water during an autopsy.
Subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) is bleeding in the space between the brain and the arachnoid membrane which is the subarachnoid space. During an autopsy, the blood from a subarachnoid haemorrhage is not easily washed away by running water. This is because it is located in this deep layer, which can trap the blood within the brain’s sulci and gyri.

questions.text: A 6-week-old boy was brought by his parents with complaints of noisy breathing, present since a few days after birth. Inspiratory stridor is heard. It subsides with prone positioning and increases with crying. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Laryngomalacia
The above clinical scenario of a 6-week-old child with inspiratory stridor which is relieved in the prone position is suggestive of laryngomalacia.
Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx and the most common cause of stridor in children. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis. The presentation is just after birth and subsides by 2 years. Stridor improves(decreases) in the prone position, and worsens during feeding. The cry is normal. Laryngomalacia leads to the collapse of supraglottic structures during inspiration which results in airway obstruction.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to OPD with a history of URTI. He also has features of mouth breathing, sleep apnoea and nasal obstruction. The mother has noticed that the child increases the volume while watching TV. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

The given clinical scenario of a child with mouth breathing. Sleep apnoea, nasal obstruction, and decreased hearing points towards the diagnosis of serous otitis media secondary to adenoid hypertrophy. Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion would be the most appropriate management.
Adenoid hypertrophy causes typical facies characterized by an elongated face with a dull expression, an open mouth, a hitched-up upper lip, prominent upper teeth causing crowding (malocclusion of teeth), a high arched hard palate (due to loss of tongue’s molding action on the palate), and a pinched-in nose due to disuse atrophy of the alae nasi.

choices.text: Iron and folic acid if the Hb <11 g/dl
Iron and folic acid if the Hb <9 g/dl
Iron and folic acid only in 3rd trimester
Iron and folic acid for 6 months antepartum and for 6 months postpartum

questions.text: Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat programme (AMB), the Government of India advocates giving
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Iron and folic acid for 6 months antepartum and for 6 months postpartum
Under the AMB program, the government of India advocates giving iron and folic acid for 6 months antepartum and for 6 months postpartum.

choices.text: Best corrected visual acuity of less than 1/60 in the better eye
Best corrected visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye
Presenting visual acuity of worse than 3/60 in the better eye
Presenting visual acuity of worse than 6/60 in the better eye

questions.text: The World health organisation (WHO) definition of blindness is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Presenting visual acuity of worse than 3/60 in the better eye
WHO has recently revised its definition for blindness. As per the new definition, blindness is defined as presenting visual acuity of worse than 3/60 or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10° in the better eye.
Refractive error is the main cause of visual impairment in ages 0-49 years, followed by cataracts, amblyopia, and corneal opacity. However, in the age group >50 years, cataract is the major cause, followed by refractive errors and surgical complications of cataract.

questions.text: What is the target Maternal mortality rate and Under 5 mortality rate to be achieved by 2030?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

70 and 25 respectively

The target maternal mortality rate and Under-5 mortality rate to be achieved by 2030 are 70 and 25, respectively.
SDG(Sustainable development goals) comprises of 17 goals and 170 targets for Agenda 2030.
The SDGs adopted in 2015 aim to reduce Under-5 mortality to as low as 25 per 1000 live births by the year 2030.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a history of ear discharge in the left ear for the past 4 weeks, deep-seated ear pain for the past 1 week, and diplopia for the past 2 days. Her symptoms have progressed gradually over the past 4 weeks. Which of the following signs/syndrome is seen in the above condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Gradenigo’s syndrome

The given scenario is a typical presentation of Gradenigo’s Syndrome, which occurs secondary to petrositis (a complication of otitis media).
Gradenigo’s syndrome is a triad that consists of:
- Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (VI nerve palsy)
- Deep ear/facial pain (V Nerve involvement)
- Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)

questions.text: Which of the following features is associated with vitamin A deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bitot spots
Bitot spots are triangular, pearly-white or yellowish, and foamy spots on the bulbar conjunctiva on either side of the cornea are associated with Vitamin A deficiency.

questions.text: Which is the new online software launched under the national tuberculosis elimination program (NΤΕΡ) by the government to monitor TB patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

NIKSHAY
NIKSHAY is a web-based solution for monitoring TB patients. (The word is a combination of two Hindi words NI and KSHAY, meaning eradication of TB).
Nikshay is a web-based solution for monitoring TB patients to monitor the Revised National Tuberculosis Programme (RNTCP). This system stores information about the patient, medical history, diagnosis, co-morbidities and lab reports.

questions.text: Which of the following is a category C bioterrorism agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hanta virus
Hanta virus is a category C bioterrorism agent. All the other options are category A agents.
Bioterrorism refers to the intentional release of a harmful agent by attackers to cause diseases or fatalities within the human population or impact food crops and livestock. The aim is to instil fear among civilians or influence governmental actions.

questions.text: A 61-year-old university professor presents with a loss of vision in his left eye. He describes the sensation as a curtain being drawn over his affected eye. The patient had a history of flashing lights and floaters 7 days back. He also gives a history of having cataract surgery in the same eye 3 weeks ago. What is the likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Retinal detachment

The patient with sudden painless loss of vision has been complaining of floaters and curtain falling sign with a recent history of cataract surgery suggests the diagnosis of retinal detachment.
Retinal detachment occurs due to the accumulation of fluid between the neurosensory retina (NSR) and retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) due to a retinal tear.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female patient underwent surgery on her middle ear and a nerve was injured intraoperatively. She came a week later to OPD with difficulty in closing her eyes on the same side. Ocular examination reveals decreased corneal sensation and dryness of the cornea. Which of the following cranial nerves was most likely injured during the surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

VII
This patient with a past history of intra-op nerve injury during middle ear surgery presented with dry eye, decreased corneal sensation, and incomplete eyelid closure (lagophthalmos) due to injury to cranial nerve (CN)VII.
Lagophthalmos can be caused by conditions such as facial nerve injury, parkinsonism (reduced muscle tone), lid scarring, and proptosis. The facial nerve runs horizontally in the medial wall and vertically in the posterior wall of the middle ear. Hence, they can be injured due to surgery of the middle ear. Clinical features include dry eyes, decreased corneal sensation which can eventually lead to mild punctate epithelial changes and epithelial breakdown.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with an acute painful red-eye. An image of her eye is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acute angle-closure glaucoma
The clinical scenario and a red eye showing corneal edema and a mid-dilated and vertically oval pupil are suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma. The pupil is non-reactive to both light and accommodation.

questions.text: Family was found dead in a closed room without windows, and smoke coming from a woodfire was present. Which of the following features is likely to be seen on their bodies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cherry red hypostasis
In the case of a family found dead in a closed room with smoke from a wood fire, there is likely to be cherry red discoloration on their bodies. This discoloration is due to carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning, which can occur from smoke in an enclosed space.
The colour of postmortem staining in CO poisoning is cherry red. Carbon monoxide is a byproduct of incomplete combustion of organic materials, such as wood. When inhaled, CO binds to hemoglobin in the blood with an affinity approximately 240 times greater than that of oxygen, forming carboxyhemoglobin (COHb). This reduces the oxygen- carrying capacity of the blood, leading to tissue hypoxia.

choices.text: Observing changes in blood pressure throughout a 24-hour period
Recording and analyzing blood pressure levels over an extended period to identify patterns and predict future readings
Comparing blood pressure values between different populations based on demographics
Assessing blood pressure during exercise to evaluate cardiovascular health

questions.text: What does the term “tracking” refer to in relation to blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Recording and analyzing blood pressure levels over an extended period to identify patterns and predict future readings

“Tracking in relation to blood pressure refers to recording and analyzing blood pressure levels over an extended period to identify patterns and predict future readings.
When blood pressure levels are observed from childhood through to adulthood, individuals with higher blood pressure early on typically maintain higher levels, while those with lower levels tend to stay lower as they age. This consistent ranking of blood pressure over time is called “tracking.” This helps identify children and adolescents who are at risk of developing hypertension in the future.

questions.text: According to the MTP Act, termination of pregnancy due to contraceptive failure can be done up to what period of gestation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
20 weeks

According to the MTP Act, termination of pregnancy due to contraception failure can be done up to 20 weeks of gestation.

Upper limit of MTP:

- Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
- Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
- At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

questions.text: Ostmann fat pads are associated with which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Eustachian tube
The Ostmann fat pads are masses of fatty tissues located inferolateral to the cartilaginous eustachian tubes.
It helps keep the tube closed, protecting it from the reflux of nasopharyngeal secretions and also prevents the transmission of nasopharyngeal pressure to the middle ear.

questions.text: What is the minimum per capita space required for each worker according to the Factory Act?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

500 cu ft

The minimum per capita space required for each worker according to the Factory Act is 500 cu ft.
The Factories Act, 1948 states the following in the matters of Safety and Welfare measures:
- > 1000 Workers in a factory the appointment of ‘Safety Officers
- > 500 Workers there should be a Welfare Officer
- > 250 Workers a canteen shall be provided
- > 30 female workers-Crèche

questions.text: Which of the following terms refers to instilling a particular point of view in people’s minds and inhibiting their independent thought?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Health propaganda
The act of instilling a particular point of view in people’s minds and inhibiting their independent thought is referred to as Health propaganda.
When information is used to spread a particular systemized doctrine it is called health propaganda.

questions.text: Which of the following staging systems is used in Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Fisch staging system
The Fisch staging system is used in the case of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibromas.

choices.text: Within one hour of consuming an unknown posion

questions.text: In which of the following cases will gastric lavage be contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Strychnine poisoning
Gastric lavage will be contraindicated in a case of strychnine poisoning. Strychnine is a highly toxic substance that causes severe convulsions and muscle rigidity, which can lead to complications during the procedure, such as aspiration or further injury due to the patient’s agitation or convulsions.

questions.text: Which of the following anaesthetic agents is most suitable for cataract surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

2% lignocaine
2% Lignocaine (Lidocaine) is the infiltrative anaesthetic suitable for this patient due to its moderate duration of action, which lasts for 30-60 minutes.
Lidocaine is a local anaesthetic that can be used for peripheral nerve blockade, and topical, infiltrative, spinal, and epidural anaesthesia. The duration of infiltration anaesthesia can be prolonged by the addition of epinephrine to lidocaine (up to 120 minutes). It is also used for intravenous regional anaesthesia (IVRA) in short surgical procedures (<90 minutes) on the limbs.

choices.text: Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane
Ossicular fixation with perforated tympanic membrane
Erosion of stapes footplate with perforated tympanic membrane

questions.text: A 20-year-old pregnant female presents with conductive hearing loss of 54db, not associated with tinnitus. Pure tone audiometry shows a notch at 2000 Hz. Which of the following is correct regarding the pathophysiology of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane
The given clinical scenario of a young pregnant female with bilateral conducting hearing loss and notch at 2000Hz (Carhart’s notch) is suggestive of otosclerosis where there is an ossicular fixation with the intact tympanic membrane.
Otosclerosis is the disease of the bony labyrinth in which a normally dense endochondral layer of the bony otic capsule is replaced by irregularly laid spongy bone. It has a positive family history with an autosomal dominant trait. It is more commonly seen in fernales between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy and menopause. It may be associated with osteogenesis imperfecta and a viral infection like measles.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Wire speculum
The image shown is of a wire speculum.
Eye speculums are used to keep the lids apart during intraocular operations (e.g. cataract surgery, glaucoma surgery and keratoplasty), extraocular surgery (e.g. squint surgery, pterygium surgery), enucleation and evisceration operation, removal of conjunctival and corneal foreign bodies, cauterization of corneal ulcer, examination of the eye in a patient with blepharospasm.

questions.text: Identify the postmortem change shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Tache noire
The image shows Tache noire.
If the eyelids remain open for a few hours after death, a layer of cell debris and mucus forms a yellow triangle on the sclera at either side adjacent to the iris. The base of the triangle is towards the margin of the cornea and the apex is towards the canthus of the eye. This debris turns brown when the dust settles on them. It appears within 3-4 hours of death.

questions.text: Crippling fluorosis occurs at what levels of fluoride intake:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

> 10 mg/L

Crippling fluorosis is seen at fluoride intake >10 mg/L.

Fluorosis seen with corresponding levels of fluoride intake:
- Dental fluorosis: 1.5mg/L
- Skeletal fluorosis: 3-6mg/L
- Crippling fluorosis: >10mg/L

questions.text: A young female patient presented with a burn injury. She is covered with burns on both her upper limbs, the front of her chest and the front of her abdomen. Calculate the percentage of burns according to the rule of nines.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

36%
The percentage of burns calculated in the given patient is 36

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for balance and equilibrium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Semicircular canal

The semicircular canals that are a part of the bony labyrinth are responsible for balance and equilibrium.
The semicircular canals are three loop-shaped structures filled with endolymph fluid and lined with hair cells that detect angular acceleration in three planes (horizontal, vertical, and oblique).

questions.text: The heart of the activated sludge process is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aeration tank
The activated sludge process is a part of the secondary sewage treatment and the heart of this process is the aeration tanks.

questions.text: Which of the following has been banned by the Honourable Supreme Court of India for being infamous among doctors in sexual assault cases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Two-finger test
The two-finger test has been banned by the Honourable Supreme Court of India due to its controversial and problernatic nature in sexual assault cases.
