This test, used to assess a victim’s sexual history and physical condition, was deemed unethical and unreliable and was criticised for being invasive and degrading, often failing to provide accurate evidence while infringing on the dignity of the survivor.

Oropharyngeal swab for rapid antigen test

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mc ENT manifestation of covid is sore throat, Mc non ENT manifestation of covid is Fever.

questions.text: Following the death of a person, his family who lived abroad was unable to reach him, and hence his body needed to be preserved. Which of the following substances can typically be detected in his body, even if the person did not consume the substance shortly before death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Alcohol

Alcohol can normally be detected in visceral organs, even if the person did not consume the substance shortly before death.
After death, the body undergoes various biological processes, including putrefaction. During putrefaction, bacteria present in the gastrointestinal tract and other tissues can ferment carbohydrates, leading to the production of alcohol.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the ER with complaints of muscle twitching and tremors. He gives a history of consuming crushed seeds from a plant. Shortly after, he begins to experience refractory seizures and assumes a characteristic posture with. Arching of the back and rigid extension of the limbs. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Strychnine poisoning

The given clinical vignette suggests the diagnosis of strychnine poisoning.
Strychnine poisoning occurs if a person ingests crushed seeds of Strychnos nux vomica. If swallowed uncrushed, the seeds of nux vomica have no poisonous action. The fatal dose is 15-30 mg of strychnine or one crushed seed.
Strychnine is a competitive antagonist of glycine at the postganglionic receptors in the motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. This leads to increased activity in the motor neurons.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with complaints of headache and blurring of vision. On examination, there was a difference in visual acuity. In the right eye, it was (+5D) and in the left, it was (+1D). After the best possible correction for vision, visual acuity in the right eye is 6/18 and in the left is 6/24. On fundoscopy, no pathology could be appreciated. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Anisometric Amblyopia

The most probable diagnosis from the given scenario is Anisometric Amblyopia.
A young child with a difference of vision in both eyes that is not improved after correction for refractive error supports the diagnosis. Due to the difference in refractive power, vision in one eye gets suppressed which is not apparent on examination.

questions.text: A construction site worker is brought to emergency with complaints of excessive redness and watering in the right eye. He gave a history of some chemical that had accidentally fallen into his eye few hours back. Which of the following treatment options is best suited for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Irrigation with normal saline
The initial step in the management of a patient presenting with chemical burns is immediate and thorough irrigation with normal saline or clean water delivered through an IV tubing. This is done to prevent further damage.
Along with irrigation, contaminant elimination through mechanical means should be done (e.g. using a swab stick to remove any visible particles)

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed 3-month-old baby was brought with complaints of lethargy, vomiting and diarrhoea. Further examination confirmed the presence of jaundice, hypotonia and hepatomegaly. Ocular examination revealed a bilateral cataract that resembled a drop of oil. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Galactosemia
The clinical scenario of an exclusively breastfed infant presenting with vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice, hypotonia, hepatomegaly and bilateral oil drop cataract is suggestive of classical galactosemia.

questions.text: In a case of alcohol abuse, which of the following preservatives is used to preserve blood during an autopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

NaF+ K oxalate

Sodium fluoride (NaF) (10 mg/ml) and potassium oxalate (anti-coagulant) can be used to preserve blood during an autopsy.
Sodium Fluoride (NaF) inhibits glycolysis by preventing the breakdown of glucose, which could alter the blood alcohol content. It also has antimicrobial properties to prevent the growth of bacteria and fungi and potassium oxalate acts as an anticoagulant to prevent blood clotting and helps analyse the sample.

questions.text: Calculate the number of dependents in this family. Mr J, age 68 years, Mrs J age 59, their son’s age 30 years, his wife’s age is 27 years and grandson is 5 years old.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

66.6%
The dependency ratio for this family will be 66.6%.
The dependent population includes children Population under 15 years and above 65 years are part of the numerator used to calculate the total dependency ratio. This is because this population is considered the dependent population.

Total dependency ratio = Total population below 15 years and above 65 years / Total population in the age group of 15-64 years X 100

Here,
Family members under 15 years = 1
Family members above 65 years = 1
Total population under 15 years and above 65 years = 1+1 = 2 (Numerator)
Total population in 15-65 years group = 3
Total dependency ratio = 2/3 x 100 = 66.6%

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presented with recurrent epistaxis. There is no history of trauma. He also complained of nasal obstruction and rhinorrhea. On examination, there is a firm purplish mass on the posterior nasopharynx. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma
A young male with recurrent epistaxis and complaints of nasal obstruction with a mass on the nasopharynx suggests a diagnosis of Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.
Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular and locally aggressive tumour seen almost exclusively in adolescent males, associated with significant morbidity and occasional mortality. JNA accounts for only 0.05% of all head and neck tumours. Patients usually present with a triad of progressive nasal obstruction, recurrent epistaxis and a mass in the nasal cavity and nasopharynx.

questions.text: A man who was arrested died while he was in police custody. Who will conduct the inquest in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Judicial Magistrate

A magistrate inquest will be carried out for death under police custody.
BNSS 196/Section 176 Cr. P.C. deals with magistrate inquest in which the cause of death is not under natural circumstances. Magistrate inquest may be conducted by the District Magistrate, Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Tahsildar, or any other Executive Magistrate empowered by the State Government.

questions.text: On the day of delivery, a newborn baby is undergoing a screening test for hearing. Which of the following tests is likely to be performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Otoacoustic emissions (OAE)
A newborn baby on the same day of delivery will undergo the Otoacoustic emissions (OAE) test as a screening test for hearing.
Universal Newborn Hearing Screening (UNHS) has become a standard practice in most developed countries. The identification of all newborns with hearing loss before 6 months has become an attainable and realistic goal. The goal is to screen newborn babies before 1 month of age, diagnose hearing loss before 3 months of age and start intervention as early as possible, or latest by 6 months of age.

questions.text: In the case of anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, where is the anterior ethmoidal nerve most commonly compressed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Middle meatus
The middle meatus is the most common site of compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve causing neuralgia.
Anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, also known as Sluder’s neuralgia is caused when the anterior ethmoidal nerve, a branch of the nasociliary nerve (which is itself a branch of the ophthalmic nerve, CN V1), is compressed. The most common site of compression is at the middle meatus, where the nerve may be impinged by anatomical variations, inflammation, or other pathologies affecting the paranasal sinuses.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiencies can cause laryngismus stridulus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vitamin D

Laryngismus stridulus is primarily associated with a deficiency in vitamin D.
Laryngismus stridulus can be defined as laryngeal spasm caused by the sudden contraction of laryngeal muscles due to a reduced level of calcium. It is likely to be caused by vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D, also known as cholecalciferol, plays a significant role in calcium and phosphate levels homeostasis. Its active form, calcitriol or 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol is produced by sequential hydroxylation in the liver and kidneys. It primarily increases the serum calcium and phosphate levels. Deficiency of vitamin D leads to rickets.
